Special to The News-Letter.
New York, May 8. — The Johns
Hopkins University lacrosse team defeated Stevens yesterday by 6 goals
to 1. Stevens pressed Hopkins hard
in the first half, but the latter's detense proved impregnable.
In the second half Hopkins forged
ahead, drawing first blood with a
goal by Clary, which was quickly
followed by 5 others, putting the visitors far ahead.
The Hopkins midfield defense played especially well and kept Brewer,
Hamilton and MacDonald, the Stevens stars, completely out of the
game.
Howe, who was on a Yale crew,
played a good game at coverpoint
for Stevens, and after a long run
just missed a goal by a few inches.
The line-up:
Stevens — Humphreys, g.; Polhemus, p.; Howe, cp.; Hamilton, id.;
Barnch, 2d.; Bartlett, 3d.; Bell, c.;
Manger, 3a.; Cunningham (captain),

Paulus, for Tappan; Entwistle, for

Hopkins; Nestler, Stevens. Goal umpires — Correa, Stevens; Schmeisser, Johns Hopkins. Time of halves

NEW Y. M. C. A. OFFICERS
At a meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
in Levering Hall. Wednesday afternoon the following officers were
elected for the coming year:
President—Dr. C. K. Swartz.
Vice president—J. F. Hunter.
Second vice president—H. B. Hering.
Recording Secretary — J. B. Reeside.
Treasurer—Charles L. Warner.
Executive Council — Dean E. H.
Griffin, F. A. Magruder, and L. W.
Parker.

At a meeting of the Trustees on
Wednesday afternoon, the following
additions to the faculty of the University were determined upon:
Prof. Adolphe Louis Terracher, of
the University of Upsala, Sweden,
to be associate professor of French
literature.
Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, of the
University of Missouri, to be professor of philosophy.
Mr. H. D. Austin, now instructor
in Amherst College, to be instructor
in French.
Professor Terracher and Mr. Austin will fill vacancies in the romance
department, caused by the resignation of Prof. Philip Ogden, who is
to become, in October, professor of
romance language in the University
of Cincinnati, and by the prolonged
illness of Prof. A. Marshall Elliott
the head of the department.
Prof. Lovejoy will take the place
of Prof. J. Mark Baldwin, who resigned a year ago, to study abroad.
His courses in 1910-11 will treat the
subjects of "Evolution" and "Ethical Theory."
Prof. Lovejoy is a bachelor of
arts of the University of California
in 1895, and received the master's
degree at Harvard in 1897. He spent
the year 1898-99 in Paris. He was
assistant professor
and associate
professor in Leland Stanford University from 1899 to 1901, and professor
of philosophy in Washington University, St. Louis, during the next
seven years. During the year 1907°8 he was also a lecturer in philosophy in Columbia University, and in
1908 he was elected professor of
philosophy in the University of Missouri.
Prof. Terracher is a Frenchman,
about 30 years of age, and studied
at the Ecole Normale, the Sarbonne,
the Ecole des Hautes Etudes and the
He is a bachCollege de France.
elier-es-lettres, a licencie-es-lettres
and an agrege, the last named degree
which he received with first honors
in 1903, bearing with it the right to
a professorship in the higher educational system of the French Government. For three years after graduation he held a fellowship in the
"Foundation Thiers," an institution
for research similar to the Carnegie
Institution. For the last three years

THE NEWS-LETTER, May 9, 1910.
HOPKINS GRADUATE DIES ATHLETIC
Mr. Vincent Adams Renouf, son of
Dr. Edward H. Renouf, collegiate
professor of chemistry, died last
Wednesday, of typhoid fever at
Tien Tsin, China.
Shortly after completing the undergraduate course at Hopkins, Mr.
Renouf entered the Chinese customs service under Sir Edward
Hart. He then received the appointment to the chair of history in the
Imperial Chinese University, which
position he held till his death. While
studying at Hopkins, Mr. Renouf took
an active part in student affairs. He
was an editor of the News-Letter,
historian of his class, and member of
his class executive committee and
relay team. He received his A. B.
in 1890, but remained at Hopkins
another year taking graduate work
in history. Mr. Renouf was a member of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity
and of the Phi Beta Kappa Society.

NOMINATIONS HULLABALOO POSTPONED .JAMAICAN

Nominations for the officers and
members of the next year's Athletic
Board were made at a mass meeting
of the student body, held last Monday. The election will take place
today. Heretofore the nominations
and elections have always been held
in the fall, but the constitution has
now been revised so that the Athletic Board for the next collegiate
year is elected in advance. John
Holmes, who has served two terms
as president, was unanimously renominated. The other nominations
were:
Vice presidents — Richard S. McCabe and Alan M. Chesney.
Secretary — Harry C. Burgan and
George M. Gillet, Jr.
Graduate Delegate—J. F. Hunter
and C. G. Kelly.
Medical Delegate—Gilbert M. Horrax.
Alumni Delegate — Horace Burroughs.
Faculty Delegates—Dr. Ronald T.
Abercrombie. and Dr. Edward Renouf.
Senior Delegates — Edmund B.
Clary, James R. Wolfe, E. C. Stollenwerck and Harvey C. Musser.
Junior Delegate — John S. Fulton,
Jr.
Sophomore Delegates — Ernest J.
Pieper and Clarence C. Porter.

caused so much interest, delivered a
lecture, Friday, April 15, at the University of Pennsylvania, on the sunjeet of "The Chief Causes whichHave

29, 1910, at five oclock p.m., on "The
Roman `Colonia' as an Instrument for
the Spread of Roman Influence and
Culture."

Special to The News-Letter.
New York, May 8. — The Johns
Hopkins University lacrosse team defeated Stevens yesterday by 6 goals
to 1. Stevens pressed Hopkins hard
in the first half, but the latter's detense proved impregnable.
In the second half Hopkins forged
ahead, drawing first blood with a
goal by Clary, which was quickly
followed by 5 others, putting the visitors far ahead.
The Hopkins midfield defense played especially well and kept Brewer,
Hamilton and MacDonald, the Stevens stars, completely out of the
game.
Howe, who was on a Yale crew,
played a good game at coverpoint
for Stevens, and after a long run
just missed a goal by a few inches.
The line-up:
Stevens — Humphreys, g.; Polhemus, p.; Howe, cp.; Hamilton, id.;
Barnch, 2d.; Bartlett, 3d.; Bell, c.;
Manger, 3a.; Cunningham (captain),
2a.; Brewer, Ia.; MacDonald, oh.;
Foster, ih.
Hopkins — Sears, g.; Schmeisse:
(captain), p.; Keith, cp.; Rawley,td.;
Hopkins, 2d.; Gillet, 3d.; Wolfe, c.,
Tappan, 3a.; Gail, 2a.; Clary, Ia.;
Stockett, oh.; Hulburt, ih.
Goals — Clary (3), Tappan, Hulburt, Stockett, MacDonald. Substitute — Lambelet, for Manger; Stillman, for Foster; Easter, for Gail;
Paulus, for Tappan; Entwistle, for
Polhemus. Referee — T. Brown, Toronto. Timekeepers — Makeljohns
Hopkins; Nestler, Stevens. Goal umpires — Correa, Stevens; Schmeisser, Johns Hopkins. Time of halves
—Thirty-five minutes.
NEW Y. M. C. A. OFFICERS
At a meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
in Levering Hall. Wednesday afternoon the following officers were
elected for the coming year:
President—Dr. C. K. Swartz.
Vice president—J. F. Hunter.
Second vice president—H. B. Hering.
Recording Secretary — J. B. Reeside.
Treasurer—Charles L. Warner.
Executive Council — Dean E. H.
Griffin, F. A. Magruder, and L. W.
Parker.

At a meeting of the Trustees on
Wednesday afternoon, the following
additions to the faculty of the University were determined upon:
Prof. Adolphe Louis Terracher, of
the University of Upsala, Sweden,
to be associate professor of French
literature.
Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, of the
University of Missouri, to be professor of philosophy.
Mr. H. D. Austin, now instructor
in Amherst College, to be instructor
in French.
Professor Terracher and Mr. Austin will fill vacancies in the romance
department, caused by the resignation of Prof. Philip Ogden, who is
to become, in October, professor of
romance language in the University
of Cincinnati, and by the prolonged
illness of Prof. A. Marshall Elliott
the head of the department.
Prof. Lovejoy will take the place
of Prof. J. Mark Baldwin, who resigned a year ago, to study abroad.
His courses in 1910-11 will treat the
subjects of "Evolution" and "Ethical Theory."
Prof. Lovejoy is a bachelor of
arts of the University of California
in 1895, and received the master's
degree at Harvard in 1897. He spent
the year 1898-99 in Paris. He was
assistant professor
and associate
professor in Leland Stanford University from 1899 to 1901, and professor
of philosophy in Washington University, St. Louis, during the next
seven years. During the year 1907°8 he was also a lecturer in philosophy in Columbia University, and in
1908 he was elected professor of
philosophy in the University of Missouri.
Prof. Terracher is a Frenchman,
about 30 years of age, and studied
at the Ecole Normale, the Sarbonne,
the Ecole des Hautes Etudes and the
He is a bachCollege de France.
elier-es-lettres, a licencie-es-lettres
and an agrege, the last named degree

THE NEWS-LETTER, May 9, 1910.
HOPKINS GRADUATE DIES ATHLETIC
Mr. Vincent Adams Renouf, son of
Dr. Edward H. Renouf, collegiate
professor of chemistry, died last
Wednesday, of typhoid fever at
Tien Tsin, China.
Shortly after completing the undergraduate course at Hopkins, Mr.
Renouf entered the Chinese customs service under Sir Edward
Hart. He then received the appointment to the chair of history in the
Imperial Chinese University, which
position he held till his death. While
studying at Hopkins, Mr. Renouf took
an active part in student affairs. He
was an editor of the News-Letter,
historian of his class, and member of
his class executive committee and
relay team. He received his A. B.
in 1890, but remained at Hopkins
another year taking graduate work
in history. Mr. Renouf was a member of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity
and of the Phi Beta Kappa Society.

NOMINATIONS HULLABALOO POSTPONED .JAMAICAN

Nominations for the officers and
members of the next year's Athletic
Board were made at a mass meeting
of the student body, held last Monday. The election will take place
today. Heretofore the nominations
and elections have always been held
in the fall, but the constitution has
now been revised so that the Athletic Board for the next collegiate
year is elected in advance. John
Holmes, who has served two terms
as president, was unanimously renominated. The other nominations
were:
Vice presidents — Richard S. McCabe and Alan M. Chesney.
Secretary — Harry C. Burgan and
George M. Gillet, Jr.
Graduate Delegate—J. F. Hunter
and C. G. Kelly.
Medical Delegate—Gilbert M. Horrax.
Alumni Delegate — Horace Burroughs.
Faculty Delegates—Dr. Ronald T.
Abercrombie. and Dr. Edward Renouf.
Senior Delegates — Edmund B.
Clary, James R. Wolfe, E. C. Stollenwerck and Harvey C. Musser.
Junior Delegate — John S. Fulton,
Jr.
Sophomore Delegates — Ernest J.
Pieper and Clarence C. Porter.
